article.title: Controlling the magnetism of oxygen surface vacancies in strontium titanate $\mathrm {(SrTiO_3\!)}$ through charging

choices: The electronic band structure of SrTiO3.
The spin density distribution of a single oxygen vacancy in SrTiO3.
A schematic representation of a single oxygen vacancy on a TiO surface of SrTiO3.
The charge density distribution of a single oxygen vacancy in SrTiO3.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 1(a), what is the approximate energy level (relative to the Fermi level) of the deep-gap bound state attributed to the oxygen vacancy?
What does the charge redistribution pattern in Figure 2(c) illustrate?
choices: The formation of a 2D electron gas at the SrTiO3 surface.
The antiferromagnetic coupling between neighboring Ti atoms.
The transfer of electrons from the vacant oxygen site to the neighboring Ti atoms.
The effect of an electric field on the charge density distribution.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2(b) depicts the electron spin asymmetry. What does the antisymmetry of this map indicate?
choices: The presence of an external magnetic field.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Figure 3(a), what happens to the magnetic moment of the Ti atoms as the number of electrons in the system is increased?
choices: The magnetic moment decreases and eventually vanishes.

multiple_choice_question.text: Based on Figure 3(c), what is the most stable charge state of the oxygen vacancy over the widest range of chemical potentials?
Figure 4(a) shows the PDOS for a triple oxygen vacancy. How does the presence of multiple vacancies affect the electronic structure compared to a single vacancy (Figure 1(a))?
choices: The vacancy level shifts to a higher energy.
The vacancy level broadens and shows multiple peaks.

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of magnetic coupling is observed between the Ti atoms neighboring the linear triple oxygen vacancy chain in Figure 4(b)?
choices: It depends on the charge state of the vacancy cluster

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Figure 5(c), how does the formation energy of the linear triple oxygen vacancy cluster change as the chemical potential is increased from -3 eV to -1 eV?
Figure 5(a) depicts the Bader charge of Ti atoms near the vacancy chain. What can be concluded about the charge distribution upon electron depletion (hole doping)?
choices: The charge is uniformly removed from all Ti atoms.
The edge Ti atoms lose charge more readily compared to the central ones.
The central Ti atoms lose charge more readily compared to the edge ones.
The charge distribution remains unaffected by electron depletion.
